abstract.p: Kevin Egan letter on Bruce Bartlett's Aug 22 article holds Vice Pres Al Gore's tax-cut plan might help reduce income inequality, while Gov George W Bush's plan would widen gap between rich and poor

block.p: Bruce Bartlett (Op-Ed, Aug. 22) worries that Al Gore's preference for tying tax cuts to specific taxpayer behavior is little different from direct spending; he then contrasts that proposal to George W. Bush's across-the-board cuts, a difference from which he deduces an ultimately lower cost for the Bush plan.

But if Mr. Bartlett wants to be intellectually consistent, he should also decry the enormous range of business tax deductions for specific taxpayer behavior, which cost the government many times the amount that Mr. Gore's proposals would.

Bruce Bartlett (Op-Ed, Aug. 22) worries that Al Gore's preference for tying tax cuts to specific taxpayer behavior is little different from direct spending; he then contrasts that proposal to George W. Bush's across-the-board cuts, a difference from which he deduces an ultimately lower cost for the Bush plan.

But if Mr. Bartlett wants to be intellectually consistent, he should also decry the enormous range of business tax deductions for specific taxpayer behavior, which cost the government many times the amount that Mr. Gore's proposals would.

There is a further difference between the two philosophies, though, about which Mr. Bartlett remains silent: the Gore proposal might help reduce the steadily increasing income inequality in America. The Bush proposal will instead accelerate the growing division between the wealthiest and the poorest in our country.
